Plato’s myths in the Platonist tradition
8. Renaissance illustrations of Plato’s myths

Plato was a celebrated figure in the Renaissance but only a few
illustrations of Platonic mythical motifs can be found. Perhaps
Plato’s attitude to visual representation—claiming so
often that the highest philosophical knowledge is devoid of it, and
attacking poets and artists in general more than once—inhibited
and discouraged attempts to capture in painting, sculpture or prints,
the mythical scenes Plato himself depicted so vividly in words.
Perhaps artists simply felt themselves unequal to the task. McGrath
(2009) reviews and analyzes the rare illustrations of Platonic
mythical figures and landscapes in Renaissance iconography: the
androgyne of the Symposium, the charioteer of the
Phaedrus, the Cave, and the spindle of the universe
handled by Necessity and the Fates of the Republic.
